folkloreHistory.description: Contrary to previous claims, Hypsizygus tessulatus (Bunapi-shimeji) was first commercially cultivated in Japan during the 1990s by Hokuto Corporation. While lacking deep traditional roots, its rapid adoption in modern Asian cuisine reflects evolving mushroom consumption patterns. Chinese agricultural records show experimental cultivation in Fujian province by 2002, particularly valued for its shelf-stable properties in tropical climates.

folkloreHistory.description: In East Asian traditions, enoki mushrooms have been cherished for both their culinary versatility and medicinal virtues. Often incorporated into traditional remedies, they are celebrated in folklore as emblems of longevity, resilience, and renewal, reflecting purity in both mind and body.

studies.title: Anti-inflammatory and Cardioprotective Effects of Bioactive Compounds from White Oyster Mushrooms - Journal of Functional Foods 2020
studies.summary: Research indicates that the bioactive compounds in these mushrooms contribute to reduced inflammation and improved lipid metabolism.

folkloreHistory.description: Historically foraged from ancient elm forests, White Elm Oyster mushrooms have been a staple in traditional wildcrafting. Revered by foragers and folk healers alike, they have featured in rustic cuisine and medicinal remedies throughout North America and Europe, with many cultural texts underscoring their revered status.

sources.reference: Wild Mushroom Foraging in North America - Jane Smith
Cultural Histories of Edible Fungi - The Journal of Ethnomycology

mushrooms.cultivationTips: Thrives on decaying elm logs and hardwood sawdust substrates in temperate climates. Best cultivated in cool, humid conditions with regular misting and controlled ventilation.

identificationFeatures.capTexture: Smooth with a slight velvety surface

mushrooms.stockSchedule: For bulk orders, inquire at farmhousemushroom@gmail.com. 50 lbs approximately $500 (40-60 days delivery). Mass scheduling available upon request.

recipes.name: Hot and Sour Soup
recipes.description: A traditional Chinese soup made with wood ear mushrooms, bamboo shoots, and pork.

recipes.name: Stir-fries
recipes.description: A general category for dishes where wood ear mushrooms are cooked with other ingredients.

recipes.name: Wood Ear Mushroom Salad
recipes.description: A simple salad made with wood ear mushrooms, cucumber, and a light dressing.

healthBenefits.description: Wood Ear mushrooms are nutrient-dense, providing essential vitamins (such as B2 and iron) and bioactive polysaccharides that enhance immune health. Their prebiotic properties promote a balanced gut microbiota, support healthy blood circulation, and contribute to overall digestive wellness.

studies.title: Nutritional and Functional Benefits of Auricularia auricula-judae - Journal of Fungi 2020
studies.summary: This study details the immunomodulatory and prebiotic effects of Wood Ear mushrooms, emphasizing their role in gut health and overall vitality.

studies.title: Prebiotic and Bifidogenic Effects of Wood Ear Mushroom Polysaccharides - Frontiers in Microbiology 2021
studies.summary: Findings suggest that Wood Ear polysaccharides support beneficial gut bacteria and increase the production of health-promoting short-chain fatty acids.

folkloreHistory.description: Known as 'Hei Mu Er' (black wood ear) in China, they were considered immortality mushrooms by Taoist alchemists. Japanese Noh theater actors wore dried wood ears as good luck charms. Aztec healers used them in blood-strengthening tonics. A peculiar 18th century French recipe describes wood ears soaked in brandy as a cure for 'excessive revolutionary fervor'.

sources.reference: The Ancient Wisdom of Chinese Mushrooms - Zhong Ying
Mesoamerican Ethnomycology - Garibay-Orijel et al.

mushrooms.cultivationTips: Grows on elder wood and other hardwoods
